title: How League of Legends broke me as a player and individual
body:
I've had this thread in mind for quite some time, unsure whether my disdain for the game was the reason for the path I (and others) have taken. To elaborate, I will summarize my League of Legends ranked history from the beginning to now. 

Preseason 6 was when I started playing, and about midseason I decided to play only rankeds, which with dedication and the many games I played, maining Yasuo, Skarner and Teemo (I know, I know), I climbed from my initial placement being Silver, to Plat. During this period I have never been hardstuck, never been on a win/losing-streak-deathspiral. I was content with the rank I acquired during my first season as a Top/Jungle player. 

I was greatly enjoying the game to the point of playing up to 10 games every day. League was the only game I wanted to play and Diamond the rank I strived to achieve. I was ambitious, determined, a winner. I would annihilate everyone in my path. Don't play Yasuo they say? Yasuo. Yasuo is not a champion for new players? Yasuo. I was so proficient and determined at the champion that I knew every matchup, knew how to defeat every Riven player on this damn ladder. (This used to be a skill matchup)

That was, until Riot decided to gradually nerf Yasuo out of Toplane, from changing Trinity's path(Zeal) to changing Yasuo's fluent playstyle in S7 by nerfing E and transferring power into his Q. I was extremely displeased by these changes, because I knew that they weren't right. Every Yasuo player knew. The problematic aspects of his kit were Q allowing an experienced player to win otherwise difficult melee matchups, and Windwall - the bane of ADCs and mages. Yasuo was wrongfully addressed and because of it, the same issues of Yasuo are present to this day.

As a result, I(late S6, pre7) decided to play a new lane, one that was closest to Toplane, and with Mid as my new role, I ought to play the next edgiest, mechanically intense champion on the list. Annie... I'm kidding, it's Zed. 

I was having a blast even though I was awful at Zed, I enjoyed the learning curve as I have with Yasuo. What would stop me from acquiring proficiency once again, but on a different champion? Nothing, so I thought. Midseason 7 was when I considered myself a worthy Zed player, I had surpassed 150k mastery practising primarily Zed in my ranked games. You read right, I had achieved ~150 ranked games on Zed with a winrate close to 45%. I was not discouraged (yet), as it is an expected sacrifice of learning Zed (I hate normals). These fools, I thought, these foolish Orianna players, foolish botlaners. I would get my revenge now that I have died a thousand deads on this champion. I will reap their flesh and shadows, I will finally climb back up. 

That was, until Riot decided bot lane required a higher power budget, required the aid of Ardent Censer and the cleansing of the dreadful system named autofill, - by shifting power from nowhere to the support class. People would play support, and Reddit would not be complaining about autofill. We, Riot Games, solved everything. 

Arguably they did solve this issue, but for me it was hell. The torment I choose to endure during mid-late season 7 playing Zed in a meta dominated by enchanter supports and adcarries running rampant on shields and healing. It is beyond words to describe the magnitude of tilt I, an unfortunate, still somewhat determined soul had to experience. 

The logical course of action would be to abandon Zed, abandon playing assassins altogether in favor of control mages. But believe me when I say that, there was nothing I desired more than the killing of botlaners. I would flash ult ignite even for supports if they dared to poke me, even if I knew it would mean the death of me, I would take this smug support with me, tear it to shreds as my team flames me for an inconsiderate play. The occasional satisfaction of killing was enough for me to keep playing Zed. I was an assassin for reason, no, a killer. 

I was a shadow of my former self, shaped by tilt and the hatred for balance. Not balance in its literal sense, but the game balance and paths Riot had taken this game.

I did achieve Platinum at the beginning of season 7, however ever since mid season 7, until now, I have been hardstuck in low Gold for the reasons aforementioned. Stopwatch was merely the final straw, - and even now that it is gone, the game is still equally frustrating for me to play, be it top or midlane. 

Every time I relive the fraction of determination still within me, I play myself into a winstreak quickly followed by a losingstreak. Every time I play to the peak of my ability, a surge of my former competitiveness, I am downed by games that cannot be won, games that were seemingly scripted and predetermined to send me back. Something I had never experienced during season 6.

League of Legends has taken my mind and mentality, my determination and with it, the desire to climb. 
It is time to leave, but I know I'm too weak, know I cannot uninstall until I am only a shell of hatred, deprived and escapen by all my pride and determination. Soon it will all end. This is my story.

Really the only thing I would want to go back in time to experience would be the DJ Sona hype.

The real difference between the problems we had before and the problems we have now lies in isolation. We could ban warwick, kassadin, etc... we could negotiate for role selection (and yes most of the time people were not total douchenozzles and would be open to trading roles). The players have no recourse now when minions are auto pushing, or when death timers were raised and made the game incredibly snowbally, or when one item is so overwhelmingly strong only strong users of that item are viable. We had the tools to deal with the problems we had then, but there's nothing we can do about the problems we have now.

I understand your frustration with this game but I have a an easy solution. Stop playing the game for a little while and then come back. If you still don't like it, then quit. 

Yay, downvotes.

Stop playing a a game no longer being enjoyed?

The fuck do you think this is? A hobby?!

You would be right. That is a perfectly valid and mature option.

But it is hard to let go of something you have put much time into and for which you still find rare moments of bliss from. The thing most players writing posts like this one though is for the "balance" of the game to be more in balance. That or to be skewed towards the champs they play. I've since season 3 I believe. Almost exclusively ranked once I hit 30. And the balance team has gone from trying to achieve actual balance to making flavor of the week or month op champs which are merely swapped with the passing of each new meta. I much prefer - and it is within their ability to do so - a game that is balanced around... balance.

It's a dopamine addiction is all.

If they can hook you on a dopamine release, then you'll spend far more hours chasing that same rush, even if they remove it. 

There's no reason for them to make a balanced game, if they can make a game that will better get players to keep playing for far less effort and resources.

Then people should start relying on their thinking rather than their feelings and then they'll be happy. 

Even if people don't do this to change, they should at least trust their angry and distress towards this game.

Everyone's always an animal, but no one will always think rationally.

Even the most rational of thinkers could experience a dopamine addiction, but the least rational of thinkers will not be swayed by their rational thoughts.
In effect, riot just needs to appeal to the lowest common denominator, because we aren't perfectly rational creatures. 

And people's sunk costs and dopamine addictions will keep them habitually coming back.

> [{quoted}](name=deadlychuck,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=ZElOXhEp,comment-id=00040001000100000000,timestamp=2018-03-06T17:55:38.019+0000)

> And people's sunk costs and dopamine addictions will keep them habitually coming back.

I really think you're overusing the term dopamine addiction to a kind of stupid degree. People truly are not that simple, and if it was simply a dopamine release then we would get it from other sources and be addicted to literally everything. It's absolutely ridiculous to say that the only reason people do things is because of a dopamine rush, sounds like something from a high schooler who just took biology for the first time.

Don't get me wrong, there are other reasons that people will come back to play a game that they haven't played in a while, or know doesn't succeed in providing the same experience that they want out of it. 

Which is why i brought up people's sunk costs. 
Barrier to Entry
Nostalgia 

But the fact of the matter is that people generally aren't going to behave rationally and will often behave based on habits. If you played a game every day for a year, then you can be sure that you're going to feel weird if you go without playing the game for a week. 

Really, i think that difficulty quitting league has more to do with cognitive ease than specifically some kind of dopamine addiction. The point however, is that riot tailors their game to produce those kind of "exciting" and "intense" moments, which is more akin to someone trying to maximize dopamine releases, rather than someone trying to develop a well designed and compelling game.

Well, that sounds like a real problem. If you have an addiction, try tearing yourself away from the game. Go outside or on a camping trip. Go hang out with friends, and if you don't have any friends, go to a public place and try to get some. Do whatever. Yell out loud and attract attention. You're bound to get some people interested in you. Just talk about anything one you find someone. Ask questions and keep eye contact. Always tell the truth because you want a real friend. Just do anything to divert your attention away from the game. Even shows could do the trick. Once you don't think you need it anymore, try playing again and I can almost guarantee that you will be happier playing and it won't be as important to you, which will also help you grow as a person and player. 

That's my advice. Try it or not.

I'm really not addicted to League at this point. It took me a few years, and having quit playing all together for months, but now i play to keep up to date to see where the state of the game is, specifically waiting patiently for it to crumble under it's own weight. 
A few year ago, back in 2016, i said that at the current rate of change, assuming that no massive unexpected competitor in the market, league probably had 4 years before they'd move the game so far that they'd exhaust their market and struggle to appeal to their split audience, as they started to hemorrhage players. Not to say that the game will be dead by 2020, but rather you will see it start to wane from a metaphorical death by a thousand cuts. 

And i think everyone can appreciate how there's a primal fascination to watch something big fall. See when the straw breaks the camel's back and what parts are the first to buckle under the pressure.
That's kinda messed up. I don't think that'll happen but I'll keep playing in the meantime!

I completely understand but if something doesn't make you happy anymore, stop doing it. You'll actually be happier if you do and then nothing is lost. 

Also, I like how the game is right now to be honest. I actually feel like I'm good now. Like actually good with map awareness, objective control, and micro. So anything that Riot does I'm fine with unless they like make the game unplayable in some way, which would be very difficult to do. I like it when here things are added and the meta is shaken. It keeps the game exciting in my opinion.

Changing up the meta is fine - but not empowering certain champs or roles to the point that it completely negates others from being playable. Like a good disengage comp winning in a meta for disengage is fine; however, a poorly executed disengage comp should not beat a perfectly played hard engage comp just because disengage is the meta. Does that make sense?

Similarly, I'm fine if gp, vlad, and tanks are the meta in top right now, but it doesn't mean they should auto-win if I pick something other than meta toplaner at the moment. If they play equal to me or better, that's fine - they should win because the current meta gives them an advantage all-else being equal. However, if I clearly play 10x better than my lane opponent, they shouldn't be able to beat me just because I'm not on a meta champ. Get where I'm coming from?

And that is the problem. Stuff has been empowered TOO far towards enforcing the meta in recent history. Ever since juggernaut rework in my opinion, many patches have gone from trying to help balance things out while changing what's meta to intentionally grossly overpowering certain champs or roles and trying to enforce said champs/roles/comps as a meta that must be followed if you want a fair chance at winning. When meta comp executed poorly beats non-meta but perfectly rounded out comp executed at average level, you have a problem in my opinion. Because then it is almost entirely about the draft - rather than making it somewhat about team comp but still allowing 2 decent team comps to come down to player skill and teamwork moreso than what champs are locked. That's all I'm saying.

True. Champions fall in and out of meta, but you think that Riot favors some champions over others. I don't think this is true.

Look at the Volibear buffs. He was crap tier for so long and now he's OP. I guess Riot really favored him for the past year. Also, Zoe got nerfed hard last patch or two patches ago (I can't remember) to the point of almost garbage. Buffs are on the PBE but that's only because she was so bad. One champ I do have a problem with is Tristana. She's just too strong. That's why ban her every game. That's what it's there for. Still, before the stars and planets aligned to make her so strong, she was absolute garbage. Caitlyn super strong back in season 6 and now she's not at all. Riot nerfed her into the ground. Assassins were busted at one point. Now they're not. I don't think Riot favors certain champions because...

The meta is always in flux. People are always in flux. Life is always in flux.

> There are plenty of other games to enjoy

Except there really aren't. Many games have adopted a similar design philosophy to league, and it makes them completely unplayable to me. Let alone trying to play long enough to get proficient. 
If I enjoyed single player games, then i'm sure there'd be plenty of games to play, but virtually every MMORPG wants to imitate league's action oriented combat. 
There's no middle ground anymore, either you've got a painfully slow boring turn based (generally single player) RPG, or you've got an action RPG, which will completely dispose as much of the RPG aspect of the game as possible, to stuff as much action as they can fit into it.

Outside of that the current market bubble is on Arena Deathmatch shooters like fortnite, which I don't have any interest in playing.

Edit: Oh, and just to be clear, it's not only me who finds many of the games adopting these philosophies unplayable. Many devs (basically all of them) which have attempted to shift the design of their existing titles or new titles towards action have seen much worse sales and/or community feedback.
